name: q17_9
solnTex:
The curve is given by $Re^{it}$ for $t\in[-\pi,\pi]$. Then $|dz|=Rdt$ and the integral becomes
\[\int_{-\pi}^\pi\frac{R}{\left|Re^{it}-a\right|^2}dt.\]
This is secretly a Dirichlet problem. We want the integrand to look like the Poisson kernel, which takes the form (see the proof of Harnack's inequality)
\[\frac{R^2-r^2}{\left|Re^{it}-re^{i\theta}\right|^2}.\]
Thus we want to look at the integral
\[\int_{-\pi}^\pi\frac{R}{\left|Re^{it}-a\right|^2}dt=\frac{2\pi R}{R^2-r^2}\frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\pi}^\pi\frac{R^2-r^2}{\left|Re^{it}-re^{i\theta}\right|^2}u(Re^{it})dt\]
where $u=1$ and $a=re^{i\theta}$. Because this is the Dirichlet solution, the integral (along with the $\frac{1}{2\pi}$) becomes $u(a)=1$, so our answer is
\[\frac{2\pi R}{R^2-|a|^2}.\]
